bestBHT.bht: Love is the unifying principle behind the entire law, encompassing commandments such as not killing, committing adultery, stealing, and coveting. While the commandment of not bearing false witness is omitted in ancient manuscripts, it does not diminish the significance of love in fulfilling the law. This love for our neighbor is referred to as the royal law, summarizing and epitomizing all other commandments. Upholding this commandment prevents fraud, injustice, oppression, falsehood, adultery, murder, theft, and covetousness, while nurturing peace, preserving brotherly love, and displaying obedience to God's law.

Henry Alford: Thou shalt not bear false witness" is omitted in almost all our most ancient authorities.
Comprehended, i.e. brought under one head,— 'united in the one principle from which all flow.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: For the [commandments], Thou shalt not kill, Thou shalt
not commit adultery, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not covet, and
whatever other commandment [there may be], it is summed up," &c.
The apostle refers here only to the second table of the law, as love to our neighbor is what he is treating of.
The clause, 'Thou shalt not bear false witness,' is wanting in all the most ancient manuscripts.
Albert Barnes: All the commands which follow are designed as an illustration of the duty of loving our neighbor.
If this command were fulfilled, it would prevent all fraud, injustice, oppression, falsehood, adultery, murder, theft, and covetousness.
And if every man would do to others as he would wish them to do to him, all the design of the Law would be at once fulfilled.
Marvin Vincent: The law is normally a unit in which there is no real separation between the commandments."
Summed up in one word." The verb is compounded, not with head, but with its derivative kefalaion the main point.
The Greek idiom is, it is summed up in the thou shalt love, the whole commandment being taken as a substantive with the definite article.
John Calvin: For this, Thou shalt not commit adultery, etc."
...the import of the whole law is, that love towards one another ought to be exercised by us
Obedience to magistrates is not the least thing which tends to nourish peace, to preserve brotherly love.
Philip Schaff: This saying, lit, ‘word,’ a term applied to the commandment.
Thou shalt love, etc. The commandments were more than prohibitory, as this recapitulation by Moses plainly showed; see marginal references also.
The seventh commandment here precedes the sixth, as elsewhere in the New Testament (Mark 10:19, received text; Luke 18:20; James 2:11).
Archibald T. Robertson: The use of ου with the volitive future in prohibitions in place of μη and the imperative or subjunctive is a regular Greek idiom.
It is summed up (ανακεφαλαιουτα). Present passive indicative of ανακεφαλαιοω, late literary word or 'rhetorical term'...
The quotation is from Leviticus 19:18... it is called βασιλικος νομος (royal law).
John Gill: So far as a man loves his neighbour, whether more near or distantly related, he fulfils the law, or acts according to it.
This is the summary and epitome of them; so Christ reduces the laws of the first table to the head of love to God, and those of the second to the head of love to the neighbour.
That is, it is of no importance which stands first or last in it: it follows.
John Wesley: If there be any other — More particular Commandment — Toward our neighbour; as there are many in the law.
It is summed up in this — So that if you was not thinking of it, yet if your heart was full of love, you would fulfil it.

bhtAttempts.bht: Love is the fulcrum upon which the entire law leans. The commandments Thou shalt not kill, Thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not covet, and any other commandment are all united in the principle of love. In fact, the second table of the law, which pertains to our relationship with our neighbor, is the focus of this discussion. Love for our neighbor encompasses all these commandments, as well as the omitted commandment of not bearing false witness. This love is the royal law, the summary and epitome of the entire law. If we truly follow this command, it would prevent all forms of fraud, injustice, oppression, falsehood, adultery, murder, theft, and covetousness. In fulfilling this commandment, we maintain peace and preserve brotherly love, as well as demonstrate our obedience to God's law.

Love is the fulcrum for the entire law, summarizing the commandments of not killing, committing adultery, stealing, and coveting. Though the commandment of not bearing false witness may be omitted, it does not negate the importance of love in fulfilling the law. This love towards our neighbor encompasses all the commandments and is the essence of the royal law. By obeying this commandment, we prevent fraud, injustice, oppression, falsehood, adultery, murder, theft, and covetousness, while nurturing peace, preserving brotherly love, and demonstrating our obedience to God.

Love serves as the fulcrum for the entire law, uniting the commandments of not killing, committing adultery, stealing, and coveting. Although the commandment of not bearing false witness may be omitted, it in no way undermines the significance of love in fulfilling the law. Love for our neighbor encompasses all these commandments and is known as the royal law. By adhering to this commandment, we can prevent fraud, injustice, oppression, falsehood, adultery, murder, theft, and covetousness, while fostering peace, preserving brotherly love, and displaying our obedience to God's law.

Love forms the foundation of the entire law, encapsulating the commandments of not killing, committing adultery, stealing, and coveting. Despite the omission of the commandment to not bear false witness, love remains the crucial principle in upholding the law. Love towards our neighbor encompasses all the commandments and is referred to as the royal law. Embracing this commandment helps prevent fraud, injustice, oppression, falsehood, adultery, murder, theft, and covetousness, while fostering peace, preserving brotherly love, and showcasing our obedience to God's law.

Love is the unifying principle behind the entire law, encompassing commandments such as not killing, committing adultery, stealing, and coveting. While the commandment of not bearing false witness is omitted in ancient manuscripts, it does not diminish the significance of love in fulfilling the law. This love for our neighbor is referred to as the royal law, summarizing and epitomizing all other commandments. Upholding this commandment prevents fraud, injustice, oppression, falsehood, adultery, murder, theft, and covetousness, while nurturing peace, preserving brotherly love, and displaying obedience to God's law.
